4.text: Top 10 Evil Actions By Usually Nice Countries

41.text:
Bhutan is an isolated Buddhist country between
China and India that forgoes measuring its

47.text:
progress by GDP in favor of GNH or “Gross
National Happiness”. Until 1999 they didn’t

53.text:
even allow Internet or TV, due to their supposed
corrupting influences. It’s all hippie love

58.text:
and Buddha statues…until you look at their
policies towards minority ethnic groups.

63.text:
In the 1990s the Bhutanese leaders decided
that the GNH didn’t apply to one of its

67.text:
large minority groups, the Lhotshampas. The
Lhotshampas are ethnically Nepalese people

72.text:
who have been in Bhutan for generations, and
were promptly ethnically cleansed from Bhutan

77.text:
territory. At the point of a gun, over a hundred
thousand people were forced from their homes

81.text:
that they had lived in for hundreds of years
into refugee camps and poverty in Nepal and

89.text:
Think this is just a land of chocolate and
weird mountain people playing on giant horns?

94.text:
No, the Swiss have dark secrets in their closet.
During World War II, while they claimed neutrality

99.text:
and sat back and rode out the war, thousands
of people deposited their money into it’s

103.text:
banks. Thousands of these account holders
were killed in the carnage of the Nazi War

107.text:
machine. Yet when the relatives tried to claim
the money, they were denied access to the

111.text:
funds, funds that the banks continued to make
interest off. Not only did the Swiss screw

115.text:
over the Nazi victims but they were also the
main bankers of the Nazis, funnelling hundreds

120.text:
of millions of dollars into the German war
effort

125.text:
Now a pillar of neutrality and bikini swim
teams, Sweden once had ambitions of ruling

130.text:
the world. Starting in the 17th century, power-hungry
Sweden started expanding its territory. Excited

136.text:
to create a vast European Realm, the Swedish
King moved his armies South in an effort to

141.text:
conquer Europe. They were able to defeat Russian
and Polish armies during what is called “The

146.text:
Deluge” by Eastern Europeans. Swedes and
their allies swarmed over Europe just as the

150.text:
Mongols did centuries earlier. They were only
stopped after they tried to finish off Russia

155.text:
and, while invading the Motherland, were defeated
by Russian Czar Peter the Great and his allies.

160.text: Sweden’s dreams of Empire were over.

166.text:
During World War II the Republic of Ireland
went above and beyond what international law

169.text:
dictated regarding a neutral stance. While
neutral Switzerland was the Nazi Banker, and

174.text:
n1eutral America kept Britain alive by supplying
tons of vital war material, Ireland decided

179.text:
to have absolutely nothing to do with either
side. Even after the existence of Nazi death

184.text:
camps emerged in the closing days of World
War II, Ireland refused to go against the

190.text:
Ireland was one of the last countries to recognize
the Third Reich and, when Hitler died, Ireland

194.text:
offered a public condolence to the German
regime. But it didn’t stop after the war;

199.text:
Irish men who had the moral courage to fight
the Fascist Nazi regime, under various Allied

203.text:
flags, returned to Irish policy that officially
discriminated against them. Called the “starvation

208.text:
order,” it was Irish government policy to
prevent employment, the use of social services,

213.text:
and pensions to any Irishman who fought in
the War. Some were even thrown in jail, while

217.text:
the rest lived under constant fear that they
would be the next to be arrested and imprisoned.

223.text:
Belgium, that half-French, half-Dutch country
sandwiched in between France and Holland,

229.text:
can’t decide whether to smoke or to surrender
to that sweet, sweet bowl of home-grown. Being

234.text:
one of the youngest countries in Europe didn’t
stop it from carving out a vast Empire in

238.text:
Africa, one 77 times the size of Belgium itself.
Called the Congo Colony, it was run by King

244.text:
Léopold II who, in almost record-time, started
sacrificing his citizens for the Congo’s

249.text:
vast resources. Eight to ten million, that’s
MILLION, were killed by the Belgian Congo

255.text:
colonial rulers as they raped and squeezed
the land in order to get more and more profit

263.text:
When Yugoslavia was quickly dismembering itself
into smaller and smaller states, Bosnia was

268.text:
always the whipping boy. Picked on by the
bully Serbia and its supposed friend Croatia,

273.text:
Bosnian citizens were quickly forced into
a number of enclaves, where they were surrounded

277.text:
by enemy forces hoping a prolonged siege would
starve them into submission.

282.text:
International delegations would visit these
enclaves on fact-finding missions. During

286.text:
a trip to one of the Sarajevo enclave, Bosnian
fighters, in an effort to manipulate the opinion

290.text:
of the world press into supporting them, relayed
to their starving people that bread would

294.text:
be arriving at a local bakery. Then, as hundreds
lined up hoping to get food, the Bosnians,

299.text:
while international cameras were rolling,
staged a mortar attack that killed 17 and

304.text:
wounded dozens more. It was later revealed
that this was only one of many attacks by

308.text:
Bosnian fighters on civilians that were publicly
blamed on Serbian forces.

315.text:
Poland or, as it is known to the rest of the
world, that place that gets the crap kicked

318.text:
out of it every other decade, was re-birthed
in 1918 (back in 1795, it had been killed,

323.text:
cut up and divided like a delicious borst
pie). Between 1918 and 1939, it lived in between

329.text:
what would become two of the greatest killing
machines in the history of the world, Nazi

333.text:
Germany and Communist USSR. So while the rest
of the world was taking bets on who would

338.text:
eat up Poland next, Poland was doing its best
to piss off all of its smaller neighboring

343.text:
countries: small countries, like itself, that
it could have allied with and combined forces

348.text: to counter these two super powers.

350.text:
In 1938, Hitler wanted Czechoslovakia. The
West decided to compromise and give him a

355.text:
piece, called the Sudetenland, but Hitler
instead took the whole damn country. Hitler

360.text:
was clearly on the war path, demanding living
space for the German people. Poland, instead

364.text:
of helping and offering to protect small Czechoslovakia,
stood hand-in-hand with Hitler. When Hitler

369.text:
started to carve Czechoslovakia up, Poland
actually helped the Nazis dismember the state

374.text:
by invading parts of Czechoslovakia with the
Nazis and claiming portions of the country

379.text:
for Poland. But what goes around comes around
and, not a year later, the Nazi Blitzkrieg

388.text:
Compared to North Korean death camps and mass
slaughter of innocent civilians, South Korea

392.text:
always comes out smelling like roses. However,
during the Korean War, it showcased its own

397.text:
dark side. Even before the war in 1948, on
the island of Jeju, the South Korean military

403.text:
brutally suppressed an uprising that broke
out after Korean troops fired on unarmed protesters.

409.text:
During the rebellion, tens of thousands were
killed in organized massacres throughout the

414.text:
Just after the island was finally brought
under control, North Korean forces stormed

418.text:
over the border and launched the Korean War.
South Korean officials, worried about 5th

422.text:
Column forces attacking from the rear, decided
to kill hundreds of thousands of people throughout

427.text:
South Korea that were suspected of being sympathetic
toward the advancing communists. Known as

432.text:
the Bodo League Massacre, it has only recently
been declassified by the South Korean government.

439.text:
During the spice rush at the dawn of the merchant
era, Holland was able to corner the nutmeg

444.text:
market. In an effort to easily monitor and
control the trade of nutmeg, Dutch officials

448.text:
killed all nutmeg trees on neighboring islands,
and created vast nutmeg and mace plantations

453.text: on the small island of Run.

455.text:
In the process of setting up their very own
Nutmeg Island, the Dutch were ruthless with

459.text:
the local population, killing any that got
in their way and forcing the survivors to

464.text:
work under horrible conditions and handing
out brutal punishments to anyone who traded

468.text:
Nutmeg with ships other than the Dutch. The
island was so valuable that it was exchanged

474.text:
for the island of Manhattan, insuring that
New Amsterdam would become New York.

481.text:
When asbestos was first discovered, it was
the superhero of mined ore. Its heat tolerance

485.text:
was incredible and people thought, by putting
it in their houses, that fires would be a

489.text:
thing of the past. They didn’t stop at houses
and it was installed everywhere, including

493.text:
insulation of schools, and public buildings.
They then discovered one little drawback…it

502.text:
Canada, a bastion of workers’ rights, quickly
banned anything containing even the tiniest

508.text:
bit of asbestos, along with the rest of the
industrial world. Yet with large asbestos

513.text:
mines that employed lots of people, Canada
couldn’t just stop mining the cancer rocks…you

518.text:
know for the good of mankind. No, Canada continues
to export asbestos to Third World countries,

525.text:
even though they know that each package is
basically the Grim Reaper wrapped up in white

529.text:
plastic. Friendly Ol’ Canada is the only
western country to export asbestos, and actually

535.text:
fights international regulations that would
prevent it from exporting all that cancer.

540.text:
When other countries try and add warnings
on asbestos packaging, Canada exerts pressure

545.text:
to stop this even though, inside the country,
a plethora of regulations not only require

550.text:
asbestos to be clearly marked but also basically
require a space suit to handle it. Canada

556.text:
says that it only exports to customers that
take the greatest of safety measures, yet

560.text:
studies show developed countries, the only
ones that haven’t yet banned it, have virtually

565.text:
no safety regulations regarding asbestos.
In short, whole generations handling asbestos

571.text: will grow up with horrible forms of lung cancer.
